TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit HtmlMeta extends System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlControl

Docs.summary: Allows programmatic access to the HTML tag on the server.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The HtmlMeta control provides programmatic access to the HTML `<meta>` element on the server. The HTML `<meta>` element is a container for data about the rendered page, but not page content itself. The `<meta>` tag is placed between the opening and closing HTML `<head>` elements. Each `<meta>` element describes a metadata property name and its associated value.
Use the HtmlMeta control's <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta.Name%2A> property to specify the metadata property name, and the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta.Content%2A> property to specify the metadata property value. Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta.Scheme%2A> property to specify additional information to user agents on how to interpret the metadata property. Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta.HttpEquiv%2A> property in place of the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta.Name%2A> property when the resulting metadata property will be retrieved using HTTP.
You can get a reference to the page `<head>` element using the <xref:System.Web.UI.Page.Header%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Page> object.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the HtmlMeta control to define HTML `<meta>` elements for a Web page. Two `<meta>` elements are defined, one listing keywords describing the page and one listing the date the page was created.
[!code-cs[System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.web.ui.htmlcont_1_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.web.ui.htmlcont_1_1.aspx)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use this constructor to create and initialize a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta> control.
The following table shows initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta>.
|Property|Initial Value| |--------------|-------------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlControl.TagName%2A>|The "meta" literal string.|
## Examples For an example of how to use the HtmlMeta constructor, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta> class overview topic.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual string Content { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the metadata property value defined by the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The Content property, together with the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta.Name%2A> property, defines a metadata property of the page.
The Content property is rendered to the `content` attribute of the resulting HTML `<meta>` element.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta> control to define HTML `<meta>` elements for a Web page. Two `<meta>` elements are defined, one listing keywords describing the page and one listing the date the page was created. The Content property is used to define the `content` attribute for each `<meta>` tag.
[!code-cs[System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.htmlcont_62_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.htmlcont_62_1.aspx)]

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual string HttpEquiv { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Gets or sets an control property that is included in the HTTP response header.
Docs.value: The name of the HTTP response header item.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the HttpEquiv property in place of the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta.Name%2A> property to identify information that should be included in the response headers of an HTTP request.
The HttpEquiv property is rendered to the `http-equiv` attribute of the resulting HTML `<meta>` element.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual string Name { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the metadata property name defined by the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The Name property, together with the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta.Content%2A> property, defines a metadata property of the page.
The Name property is rendered to the `name` attribute of the resulting HTML `<meta>` element.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta> control to define HTML `<meta>` elements for a Web page. Two `<meta>` tags are defined, one listing keywords describing the page and one listing the date the page was created. The Name property is used to define the `name` attribute of each `<meta>` tag.
[!code-cs[System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.htmlcont_85_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.htmlcont_85_1.aspx)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyorassemblyhidebysig virtual instance void Render(class System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter writer) cil managed

Docs.param: The used to render the control's content on the client's browser.
Docs.summary: Renders the control to the client's browser using the specified object.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta> control renders a <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter.SelfClosingTagEnd> HTML bracket (/>) on the `<meta>` element if the client's browser is XHTML compliant. For more information on configuring ASP.NET for non-XHTML rendering, see [NIB: How to: Configure XHTML Rendering in ASP.NET Web Sites](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/42483a54-f1ae-44e1-88e6-4370f8690149).

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual string Scheme { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a attribute used to interpret the metadata property value defined by the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The Scheme property allows you to specify a `scheme` attribute of the rendered HTML `<meta>` element. The `scheme` attribute can be used to provide user agents, such as client browsers or search engines, additional context for interpreting the metadata property.
The Scheme property is rendered to the `scheme` attribute of the resulting HTML `<meta>` element.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta> control to define HTML `<meta>` elements for a Web page. Two `<meta>` tags are defined, one listing keywords describing the page and one listing the date the page was created. The Scheme property is used for the date-related `<meta>` tag to aid user agents reading the date value.
[!code-cs[System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.htmlcont_38_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlMeta#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.htmlcont_38_1.aspx)]
